config.title: Healthy workplace assessment
config.intro_copy:
Health and safety is vital in a workplace and can protect and even improve the health of its employees.

Answer the following questions to assess your workplace. Questions 1-9 will assess whether your workplace is following the UK’s health and safety laws. 
Questions 10-12 cover issues to do 
with overall health and wellbeing.           

At the end you’ll get a list of things 
to raise with your employer.

ib.title: More on working space
ib.body:
The Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1992 state that employees need adequate working space to carry out the tasks they are responsible for. This means you need sufficient space to move about the work area and to access your work station safely. 

You also need sufficient space to store work equipment including files and documents that you need to use for your work. For more detailed information, see Useful links at the end of this tool.
ib.name: More on working space

ib.title: More on workplace temperature
ib.body:
The Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1992 state that: "During working hours, the temperature in all workplaces inside buildings shall be reasonable."
 
However, this depends on the type of workplace and whether it is a bakery, a cold store, an office or a warehouse. 

For more detailed information relevant to the health of your workplace, see useful links at the end of this tool.
ib.name: More on workplace temperature

ib.title: More on lighting
ib.body: The Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1992 recognises that different levels of lighting are required for different types of work – close, accurate work such as soldering a control panel will require higher light levels than working on a till. However, a number of different factors need to be considered, such as colour, contrast, glare and so on. For more detailed information on what is appropriate for your workplace, see useful links at the end of this tool.
ib.name: More on lighting

ib.title: More on cleanliness
ib.body:
The Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1992 state that every workplace and the furniture, furnishings and fittings should be kept clean, as well as the surfaces of floors, walls and ceilings. 

Cleaning and the removal of waste should be carried out as necessary and waste should be stored in suitable containers.
ib.name: More on cleanliness

ib.title: More on drinking water
ib.body: The Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1992 state that an adequate supply of high-quality drinking water, with an upward drinking jet or suitable cups, should be provided. If water cannot be obtained from a tap, water should only be provided in refillable enclosed containers. The containers should be refilled at least daily (unless they are chilled water dispensers where the containers are returned to the supplier for refilling).
ib.name: More on drinking water

ib.title: More on toilets
ib.body: The Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1992 state that sanitary conveniences and washing facilities should be kept clean and be adequately ventilated and lit. Washing facilities should have running hot and cold or warm water, soap and clean towels or other means of cleaning or drying. If required by the type of work, showers should also be provided.
ib.name: More on toilets

ib.title: More on rest areas
ib.body: The Workplace (Health, Safety and Welfare) Regulations 1992 state that suitable and sufficient, readily accessible rest facilities should be provided. Seats should be provided for workers to use during breaks and should be in a place where personal protective equipment need not be worn. Rest areas or rooms should be large enough and have sufficient seats with backrests and tables for the number of workers likely to use them at any one time, including suitable access and seating that is adequate for the number of disabled people at work.
ib.name: More on rest areas

ib.title: What is adequate?
ib.body:
The Health and Safety (First Aid) Regulations 1981 require employers to provide adequate and appropriate first aid equipment, facilities and people so that employees can be given immediate help if they are injured or taken ill whilst at work.

The minimum first aid provision in any workplace is:
  • a suitably stocked first aid box
  • an appointed person to take charge of first aid arrangements
  • information for employees about first aid arrangements
ib.name: What is adequate?

ib.title: Encouraging healthier eating
ib.body:
There are many ways an employer can encourage healthier eating - whatever a company's size. 

For example, vending machines could be stocked with healthier snacks, ingredients for healthier breakfasts could be provided or even just fruit to encourage healthier snacking. Very simple measures, like ensuring there is adequate food storage provision and an area to prepare food, can also really help to make it easier for people to eat better.

The British Heart Foundation has some great resources to help you kick start healthier eating in your workplace. See useful links at the end of the assessment.
ib.name: Encouraging healthier eating

ib.title: Encouraging physical activity
ib.body:
Whatever a company's size, there are many ways an employer can encourage physical activity. From simple measures - such as encouraging stair use and providing secure bike lock-up points, to organising activity challenges and competitions - there are many things that can really help a workforce become more physically active.

The British Heart Foundation has some great resources to help kick start some physical activity initiatives in the workplace. See useful links at the end of the assessment.
ib.name: Encouraging physical activity
